caseTitle: ANTHONY KWABENA ANYAN v THE HIGH COURT, ACCRA
summary: The Supreme Court of Ghana dismissed an application by Anthony Kwabena Anyan seeking certiorari to quash part of a High Court ruling that he had no interest in property attached in execution. The applicant, a sub-lessee under Edward Nassar & Co. Ltd, claimed the attached land was not the one subject to judgment and asserted ownership via a 99-year lease. The High Court had ruled the execution was wrongful and further held the applicant's interest lapsed when the head lease expired in 2007. The Supreme Court held that by initiating interpleader proceedings, the applicant placed his title in issue, thus authorizing the trial court to rule on it. It found no jurisdictional error or excess, emphasizing that certiorari applies only to patent legal errors rendering decisions nullities. The proper remedy for non-jurisdictional errors is appeal. The court also corrected the case title to 'The Republic v High Court, Accra; Ex-parte: Anthony Kwabena Anyan' under Article 129(4) to align with standard practice. The application was dismissed.
verdict: The application for certiorari was dismissed for lack of jurisdictional error; the High Court acted within its authority in ruling on the applicant's interest in the property.

rationaleHighlights: The Supreme Court has supervisory jurisdiction under Article 132 to correct jurisdictional errors in lower courts.
Certiorari lies only for patent, obvious errors of law going to jurisdiction that render a decision a nullity.
In interpleader proceedings, a claimant puts their title in issue, making it legitimate for the court to rule on it.
The trial judge acted within jurisdiction in assessing the applicant's interest in the property.
Where no jurisdictional error exists, the proper remedy is appeal, not certiorari.
The applicant's lease could not exceed the term of the head lease, which expired in 2007.
The court corrected the case title to conform with standard constitutional practice.
The application was dismissed as ill-conceived due to lack of jurisdictional defect.
